history.content: It is possible; I know other students have done it. You should, indeed, contact IEOR directly about the process.
I'm taking it right now. It was easy to get into -- I just emailed the professor.

children.subject:
1. It's okay. Kind of dry, but I suppose that's to be expected. I wouldn't say it's particularly well-designed, but it's also not chaotic.
  2. Nope, I don't think I'll have time. I also hear it's much harder. Perhaps someone else can comment on 222 more.
  3. I'm a third-year. The math is fairly elementary -- just basic probability, differentiation, systems of linear equations, etc. If I recall correctly, the professor himself said that most high school students could take the course and do just fine.
In that case, would you suggest skipping 221 and going to 222? I prefer a math-focused finance course, and from what you're saying 221 might be too basic
Hard to say. I think you should consult someone who's taken both 221 and 222.

Hey, I'm the anon who posted the student response. Just wanted to post an update now that the course is over:

  1. The course got substantially more interesting toward the end when we started talking about derivatives. The first part of the course (on valuing deterministic cash flows) was dry, but in retrospect it was necessary prep work for the later content. So I'd say it was fairly well designed (though I have no alternative to compare it against).
  2. Still not planning to take 222.
  3. The math was fairly elementary throughout.

I took the course to learn the basics of finance and to get some intuition for some of the big ideas in finance (time value of money, no-arbitrage arguments, modeling real-world phenomenon using stats/probability). So from that standpoint, overall I think I got out of the course exactly what I wanted to get out of it.

Thank you for the response! Student answerer:

1. How do you like the class? Is it a well-designed course?

2. Are you planning to take IEOR 222 (Financial Engineering Systems I) soon?

3. What year are you? What math/stat/cs courses have you taken that have prepared you? I am a freshman and want to be prepared. Thanks!

history.content:
I want to take IEOR 221 (Intro to Financial Engineering) as an undergrad. However, I understand this is a graduate course and I might not be able to get in. Is it possible?

I know I should email the IEOR advisors directly about this. Has anyone else taken an graduate IEOR course, though, and can tell me who to email? Or if it's possible or not?


Thanks.
history.subject: Taking IEOR 221 as an undergrad
